title: Correction: CSF p-tau205: a biomarker of tau pathology in Alzheimer‚Äôs disease
caption:
üî¨ Exciting update in Alzheimer's research! A recent correction highlights the significance of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) p-tau205 as a biomarker for tau pathology, a key player in Alzheimer's disease. üß† This correction clarifies that the phosphorylated tau is at threonine 205, not serine 205, enhancing the accuracy of this vital diagnostic tool. This advancement underscores the ongoing progress in neuroscience, bringing us closer to understanding and potentially treating Alzheimer's. üåü

#Neuroscience #AlzheimersResearch #Biomarkers #BrainHealth #ScientificProgress

images.title: File:Accuracy of the Phosphorylated Tau 217 (p-Tau217) Immunoassay in Detecting Amyloid Œ≤ (AŒ≤) Positivity and Tau (T) Positivity and Discriminating A+T‚àí From A+T+ Individuals.png
images.author: Authors of the study: Nicholas J. Ashton, PhD1,2,3,4; Wagner S. Brum1,5; Guglielmo Di Molfetta, MSc1; Andrea L. Benedet, PhD1; Burak Arslan, MD1; Erin Jonaitis, PhD6,7,8; Rebecca E. Langhough, PhD6,7,8; Karly Cody, PhD7; Rachael Wilson, PhD7,8; Cynthia M. Carlsson, PhD6,7,8,9; Eugeen Vanmechelen, PhD10; Laia Montoliu-Gaya, PhD1; Juan Lantero-Rodriguez, PhD1; Nesrine Rahmouni, MSc11,12; Cecile Tissot, PhD11,12; Jenna Stevenson, PhD11,12; Stijn Servaes, PhD11,12; Joseph Therriault, PhD11,12; Tharick Pascoal, MD, PhD13,14; Alberto Lle√≥, MD, PhD15,16; Daniel Alcolea, MD, PhD15,16; Juan Fortea, MD, PhD15,16; Pedro Rosa-Neto, MD, PhD11,12; Sterling Johnson, MD, PhD6,7; Andreas Jeromin, PhD17; Kaj Blennow, MD, PhD1,18; Henrik Zetterberg, MD, PhD1,7,18,19,20,21
images.description: "Receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curves for p-tau217 in detecting AŒ≤ positivity and tau positivity and to differentiating AŒ≤-positive and tau-positive individuals (A+T+) from AŒ≤-positive and tau-negative (A+T‚àí). For each ROC curve, the area under the curve is reported alongside 95% CI. For WRAP and TRIAD, AŒ≤ and tau were indexed by positron emission tomography. In SPIN, A was indexed by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) AŒ≤42/40 and T by CSF p-tau181."

title: TEAD1::NCOA2 fusion driver in primary central nervous system malignancy: case report
caption:
üî¨üß† Exciting developments in neuroscience! A recent case report highlights the discovery of a TEAD1::NCOA2 fusion as a driver in primary central nervous system malignancies. This fusion could pave the way for new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in treating these complex conditions. Understanding such genetic fusions is crucial as it opens doors to targeted treatments, offering hope for better outcomes. This finding underscores the importance of continuous research in identifying molecular drivers in brain tumors. Stay tuned as science unravels more mysteries of the brain! üß¨‚ú®

#Neuroscience #BrainResearch #Genetics #Innovation #MedicalResearch #BrainTumors #ScienceNews

title: Strong nuclear expression of HOXB13 is a reliable surrogate marker for DNA methylome profiling to distinguish myxopapillary ependymoma from spinal ependymoma
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:p>Spinal ependymoma and myxopapillary ependymoma are the two most common spinal ependymal tumor types that feature distinct histological characteristics, genetic alterations and DNA methylation profiles. Their histological distinction may be difficult in individual cases and molecular diagnostic assessment, in particular DNA methylome profiling, may then be required to assign the correct diagnosis. Expression of the homeobox gene <jats:italic>HOXB13</jats:italic> at the mRNA and protein levels has been reported as a frequent finding in myxopapillary ependymoma that may serve as a diagnostic marker for these tumors. Here, we evaluated the diagnostic role of HOXB13 immunostaining in 143 spinal neoplasms, comprising 54 histologically classified myxopapillary ependymomas, 46 histologically classified spinal ependymomas, and various other tumor types. Immunohistochemical results for HOXB13 protein were compared to molecular findings obtained by bead array-based DNA methylation and DNA copy number profiling, as well as next generation gene panel sequencing-based mutational analysis. Our findings indicate strong nuclear HOXB13 expression as a reliable diagnostic marker for molecularly confirmed myxopapillary ependymoma. Moreover, we provide evidence that differential HOXB13 protein expression is related to differential <jats:italic>HOXB13</jats:italic>-associated CpG site methylation in myxopapillary vs. spinal ependymomas, which can be assessed by targeted DNA methylation analysis. Taken together, immunohistochemistry for HOXB13 protein expression and targeted DNA methylation analysis of <jats:italic>HOXB13</jats:italic> represent useful surrogate approaches that may substitute for DNA methylome profiling in routine diagnostics and facilitate precise classification of spinal ependymal tumors. In particular, strong nuclear HOXB13 immunoreactivity may serve as a novel diagnostic criterion for the classification of myxopapillary ependymoma.</jats:p>
caption:
üî¨ Exciting news in the world of #Neuroscience! Researchers have identified the strong nuclear expression of HOXB13 as a reliable marker for distinguishing between myxopapillary ependymoma and spinal ependymoma. üéØ This breakthrough offers a new diagnostic tool, potentially replacing more complex DNA methylome profiling, making it easier and more precise to classify spinal ependymal tumors. üß†üîç

By evaluating HOXB13 immunostaining in over 140 spinal neoplasms, the study highlights how this marker can aid in accurate tumor classification, paving the way for better clinical outcomes. The findings underscore the importance of molecular diagnostics in neuro-oncology, offering a promising future for patient care. üåü

#CancerResearch #HOXB13 #Ependymoma #NeuroOncology #ScienceNews

title: A novel TEAD1::NCOA2 fusion that potentially expands the concept of supratentorial ependymoma, YAP1 fusion-positive
caption: üß† Exciting developments in neuroscience! A novel TEAD1::NCOA2 fusion has been identified, potentially expanding our understanding of supratentorial ependymoma, YAP1 fusion-positive (ST-EPN-YAP1) tumors. This discovery, made in a young child, highlights the complexity and variability of brain tumors. The tumor exhibited classic ST-EPN-YAP1 characteristics but with a unique genetic fusion, broadening our insights into pediatric brain neoplasms. With advanced imaging and RNA sequencing, this case underscores the importance of genetic profiling in accurate diagnosis and treatment planning. The patient, after a complete resection, remains healthy 100 months post-diagnosis. This finding is a beacon of hope in pediatric neuro-oncology, showcasing the power of personalized medicine. üåü #Neuroscience #PediatricCancer #BrainTumorResearch #GeneticDiscovery #MedicalInnovation

title: Essential tremor with tau pathology features seeds indistinguishable in conformation from Alzheimer‚Äôs disease and primary age-related tauopathy
caption:
üß†‚ú® Exciting developments in neuroscience! Recent research reveals that essential tremor (ET) with tau pathology shares tau seed conformations identical to those in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and primary age-related tauopathy (PART). This discovery highlights a potential path for more precise diagnosis and targeted therapies for ET patients experiencing cognitive impairments. By analyzing brain samples, scientists found significant tau seeding activity in ET cases, particularly in the temporal regions. This connection between ET, AD, and PART could revolutionize treatment approaches for these neurodegenerative conditions. Stay tuned for more breakthroughs! üåüüî¨

#Neuroscience #EssentialTremor #AlzheimersDisease #Tauopathy #BrainResearch #Neurodegeneration #ScienceNews

images.title: File:Tauopathy in Alzheimer's disease.jpg
images.author: Tulemo
images.description: This photomicrograph shows nerve cell bodies (one is indicated by the arrow) and their processes (one is indicated by the arrowhead) in the neocortex of a patient who had died with Alzheimer's disease at Braak stage VI. Tau protein is stained brown using immunohistochemistry. The tissue section is lightly counterstained with hematoxylin (light blue). The bar represents a distance of 25 microns (0.025 millimeters).
